importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article indicates the current state of food supply conditions in Gaza following the ceasefire, highlighting ongoing humanitarian challenges and the urgency of expanding aid access.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe shows the duration of Israel’s war in Gaza and the continued humanitarian crisis, emphasizing the long-term impact on food security and population welfare.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are still far below the WFP’s daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are currently operational, severely limiting aid access.
The WFP has 26 food distribution points open, up from five, but still far short of the 145 it aims to operate across Gaza.
Humanitarian aid is reaching northern Gaza via southern routes, but not in sufficient quantities to meet nutritional needs.
Many Palestinians are storing food due to fears of future supply disruptions, indicating lack of confidence in the ceasefire’s sustainability.
The US-brokered ceasefire and President Donald Trump’s 20-point plan are central to enabling increased aid delivery.
Hamas has agreed to hand over 13 of 28 deceased captives' bodies, with a commitment to deliver two more, which is a condition for reopening key crossings.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has maintained the Rafah crossing closed until Hamas fulfills its body-handing obligations.
The WFP has emphasized that full border crossings are essential to achieving food access at scale and preventing famine.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international humanitarian agency responsible for coordinating food aid to populations in crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to monitoring and reporting on food supply levels in Gaza, providing data and calling for increased humanitarian access through border crossings.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory under Israeli military control, currently experiencing a severe humanitarian crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Gaza Strip is the focal point of the food supply issue, with residents facing critical shortages due to restricted access and war damage.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Israel and Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the two active crossings allowing food to enter Gaza, and its operation is essential for humanitarian deliveries.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Israel and Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing, known as Kerem Shalom in Israel, is one of the two active points allowing food aid to reach Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its closure restricts additional humanitarian access and limits potential routes for food and aid into Gaza, especially from the south.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza, currently restricted for aid access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted access to this route, preventing large-scale aid delivery to northern Gaza, where need is most urgent.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered a ceasefire agreement and proposed a 20-point plan for Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His diplomatic role in facilitating the ceasefire and advocating full humanitarian aid is critical to the current food delivery efforts.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who has maintained the Rafah crossing closed and set conditions for reopening.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His position on the Rafah crossing and the captives’ remains directly affects humanitarian access and aid delivery in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and militant group with control over Gaza, currently under negotiation regarding prisoner remains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas has agreed to return captives’ remains, a condition for reopening crossings and allowing broader humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas responsible for announcing the return of captives' bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group confirmed the handover of two more bodies, signaling progress on a key condition for easing aid restrictions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza are critically low, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily—far below the target of 2,000 tonnes—due to just two operational crossings: Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara. Despite an increase in distribution points from five to 26, the WFP stresses that full access is required to meet the population’s needs. The US-brokered ceasefire and Donald Trump’s 20-point plan are seen as vital for enabling large-scale aid, but access remains constrained by Israeli security restrictions, including the closure of the Rafah crossing and the lack of access to Salah al-Din Street. Hamas has committed to hand over 13 of 28 captives’ bodies, with two more delivered recently, which is a key condition for further opening crossings. Many Gazans are storing food due to fear of future disruptions, highlighting the fragility of the current humanitarian situation.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
